just like you don't even know right these guys are marketing guys like they

okay we'll I'll get it done with a static site I like so sweet sounds good
to me static sites are so awesome that's why we're all here we we love the jam
stack the static sites make up small not a small a very large portion of a lot of
what we do and static sites are great because they naturally afford to search
engine optimization and they come with all of the amazing things that static
sites have inherently of being fast being able to easily push them out to
CDNs and in my opinion they're extremely cost effective versus other solutions
that require servers and stuff and even better a message AMSAT
community right there are great tools that can help us build static websites
that take a lot of the burden of this static site generation architecture off
of our backs when I got when I was given this this assignment you know take over
a marketing website all of my back-end team there go guys and they're like you
know you should try this cool new static site generator called Hugo I was like
all right this sounds great they're like it can build a 100,000 page web site in
five milliseconds or something and I'm like okay that's great I think we have
like 20 pages so if it works it works they're like sweet go for it so I
started using Hugo and honestly it was a lot of fun like the speed is incredible
and there are a lot of great things about Hugo but again as a JavaScript
developer there were a lot of sad things about Hugo for me one of them is write
in the name everything in Hugo's written and go and you know for the most part
you have a great experience but at some point or another being a JavaScript
developer I felt like I was running into barriers I was running into capability
walls that I had to either tear down or learn go and I I like go it reads well
but I'm not prepared to do that for me and what it really meant was this was a
no-go after using it for about three or four months I decided this is not
something I want to use you know for the foreseeable future it was really sad
because Hugo builds great static websites it really does but to me the
like one of the other biggest problems with Hugo is that javascript is an
afterthought with some of these static site generators and when javascript is
an afterthought and not a first-class citizen developers start to you know
when they're left to their own devices they start to do terrible things clearly
I would never do this right but it's very tempting because when you're
working with a stack that basically takes you back ten years
which is totally fine if that's where you need to end but for me I want to
take things further and I want I want a full-on JavaScript application jQuery is
attractive because you drop it in and it works we didn't want to do that we
wanted something that was going to be sustainable and you know we started
looking to looking into other static site generators and this was a problem
across a lot of the static site generators that we found is that they're
all written in languages that are not JavaScript and they all use template
England which is that are either very opinionated or you know aren't
necessarily standardized which is an evil word but basically everybody has to
learn the Oh what's your site written and well it's this so you have to learn
the stack to use it we didn't want that I wanted things to be cohesive I wanted
to be able to hire a front-end developer and say you can work on our application
you can work on the website in fact you can work anywhere because it's all just
JavaScript and that's really what I wanted I wanted to build a marketing
website I wanted to build a static website like an application because
that's the future to me you know we're working so hard on making this
experience so good and not only just a JavaScript application but I love react
I wanted to build it in react and I knew that there had to be a world where we
could merge these two things together I knew there had to be a way where I could
not worry about static site generation or not worry about all the
implementation details that go into is this static site being generated or not
like I just want to write a react application in fact like create react
app is such a prolific tool right now in the react ecosystem because it's so dead
simple I wanted to go from something like that to a static site and not
really have a lot of pain involved and so that's why I built react static a
react static is a progressive static site generator
that's a big term but progressive static site generator what is a progressive
static site generator well at the core it starts with just a static site like
you'd expect from anything else a static site that when you load a page like a
blog you'll see HTML you'll see CSS it'll be they'll have all the normal
benefits that you would get from using any other static site generator but
where most generators stop react static begins at an opportune moment it begins
to load a react application on top of your HTML file it doesn't matter what
page it was that you loaded of your static website then it loads in the
assets that you originally used to create that page be the template the
data any dependencies that it may need and invisibly to the user becomes a
react application uses something called rehydration and react rehydrates over
the existing HTML of the page the user has no idea but now they're in a
full-fledged single page app running react that means we can do some pretty
interesting things not only does that let you use whatever you want in the
react ecosystem up to that point or whatever framework you're using right
but it also allows us to do some very intelligent things with navigation and
with the regular flow of a static site from there we might want to visit a page
like an individual post where we would normally in a static site click a link
we'd have to reload the HTML download it the whole browser would freak refresh
you know you're used to this process with the static site generator and it's
fast it really is there's like a static site is fast even if you're just using
hard links we take it to the next level we load the assets that were created
that were used to create that page the users navigating to and we recreate that
page within the application the react application so there's no there's no
hard navigation it looks exactly like you're using a react application and in
fact it to the developer that's exactly how you develop it you don't have
to worry about you know proprietary routing or hooking all this up on your
own it just kind of comes for free you can do that for the entire length of the
session that the user is on your site this is fantastic because if we can
enter a page like an individual post load of react application load the
assets that were used to build it and rehydrate over the HTML we can kind of
start to get really smart about things let's say there's like three links on
the page that we can go to well react static can actually start pre loading
those links and you can even write plugins that use things like Google
Analytics to predict or the user is going to go
it'll preload these assets so that in any given case that the user wants to go
there it's instantaneous right you don't wait for anything all the data the
template everything is there and it's instant and it's such a great feeling as
a user browsing one of these websites it's having instant navigation and we
can continue doing that again throughout the entire session lifecycle that the
user has on your site so there's a lot of moving pieces here thrown around a
lot of colored boxes right but when you boil it down there's just a few basic
things that need to happen for a progressive static site to work you need
an application framework you're gonna need a way to decipher what the
templates are you can pass a date some data and you're going to produce HTML
and we have to worry about these things for every single route that you could
possibly visit as far as static route so you can possibly visit for your entire
site now this is a really small site but some sites get really big obviously you
need a tool to do that and react static is the tool that I built to help us do
that the goal that I had when building react static was inspired by reax mantra
of being just javascript I didn't want to build a proprietary
system that required you to learn new things that you're unfamiliar with or
introduced you know foreign concepts into what you're used to building I
wanted everything to feel as familiar as possible to a react application and so I
started with just some JavaScript some JSON data basically we create some
routes and let's say every route has a path right we can add a template to a
route to say which template we want to render it with and then we can assign
that some data and this data function can be asynchronous or it could be
synchronous whatever we want you can take that data from you know places in
your file system if you'd like or you can even get at a synchronously from
wherever you want use your favorite headless CMS if you'd
like and you can even use that data to generate new routes so you're not
limited in what you know before the build you can use anything you'd like to
generate routes so when you break this down all react static is doing under the
hood is taking all of your templates D duping them and giving you some really
useful reactive components like routes which is just a component that you can
import from react static and say this is what I want to render my static content
likewise when you have data that you're passing to a specific route those data
pieces get chunked out into JSON files and they're intelligently loaded through
react static and made available through things like hooks and components like
use route data so there's no complex queries happening
there's no weird data pipelining or intermediary databases it's just
straight data like you pull the data in and you push it to the routes then that
need it and you grab that data in your components and you render this concept
of assigning templates and data to routes has been around
since static sight generation began and that's what static sight generation is
all about right taking these two things and marrying them together and in my
